Puckett's 5 bands you'll want to see this week

Jeffrey Lee Puckett picks five fun things to do this week Louisville.

Puckett's 5 bands you'll want to see this week

Jeffrey Lee Puckett, jpuckett@courier-journal.com 9:18 a.m. EST December 3, 2014

Steelism is the duo of Jeremy Fetzer (left) and Spencer Cullum.(Photo: Courtesy of the artist)

1 CONNECT 2 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

1. Instrumental music, when played with imaginaton and little thought given to boundaries, can conjure emotions with substance and heft. Words optional. Steelism, which is Jeremy Fetzer on guitar and Spencer Cullum on pedal steel, make movies out of music.

WHEN: 9 p.m. Friday

WHERE: Zanzabar, 2100 S. Preston St.

COST: $6 advance, $8 day of show, available at the venue or www.zanzabarlouisville.com

The Fervor.(Photo: Submitted)

2. The Fervor is celebrating the release of a grand new single, "Moment of Truth," and the reissue of its first album, "Bleeder," with a crazy show that also features the debut of Frederick the Younger and a rare performance by Vietnamese guitarist Long Thanh Nguyen.

WHEN: 9 p.m. Friday

WHERE: Haymarket Whiskey Bar, 331 E. Market St.

COST: $5

COURIER-JOURNAL

With Counting Crows on its way, Jeffrey Lee Puckett looks at the best-selling rock albums of the 1990s.

Yelawolf(Photo: Submitted)

3. Yelawolf has been crafting one of the more weirdly inclusive hip-hop careers in recent memory, collaborating with rockers, pop singers and hip-hop icons, including Ed Sheeran, Lil Jon, Kid Rock and Eminem, who produced Yelawolf's "Radiactive," a hit in 2011.

WHEN: 8 p.m. Sunday

WHERE: Mercury Ballroom, 611 S. Fourth St.

COST: $20 at the door and online at www.mercuryballroom.com

COURIER-JOURNAL

5 spots for live music

Nutcracker in a Nutshell(Photo: Submitted)

4. "The Nutcracker" is, of couse, a holiday staple and popular with children, but a typical performance is more than two hours long and that can be a problem for short attention spans. "Nutcacker in Nutshell" shaves off an hour and leaves all the fun stuff.

WHEN: 2 and 7 p.mm. Saturday

WHERE: The Louisville Palace, 625 S. Fourth St.

COST: $17.50 and $20, available at the venue and online at www.livenation.com

Frontier Ruckus(Photo: Submitted)

5. Frontier Ruckus returns with a fresh batch of songs from songwriter Matthew Milia and a new album, "Sitcom Afterlife." The album has been pulling some great reviews and singer Anna Burch has rejoined the band for this tour. Firekid opens.

WHEN: 9 p.m. Thursday

WHERE: Zanzabar, 2100 S. Preston St.

COST: $8 advance, $10 day of show, available at the venue or www.zanzabarlouisville.com

Here Come the Mummies(Photo: Submitted)

6. Here Come The Mummies is pure novelty act in some respects, with all of the band members dressed as mummies, but the players are top-notch and their brand of funk has a charm and bounce typical of late 1970s Top 40 jams — think Ray Parker, Jr. and Bootsy, baby.

WHEN: 8:30 p.m. Friday

WHERE: Mercury Ballroom, 611 S. Fourth St.

COST: $20 at the door and online at www.mercuryballroom.com
